case_name: Pandurang Dhondi Chougule & others v. Maruti Hari Jadhav & two others

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 163 of 1963 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated October 31, 1960 of the Bombay High Court in Civil Revision Application No. 2131 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 163 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated October 31, 1960 of the Bombay High Court in Civil Revision Application No. 2131 of 1957.

facts.text: Respondents Maruti Hari Jadhav and two others moved the B.A.D.R. Court at Karad on May 26, 1949, for adjustment of the debt due to appellants Pandurang Dhondi Chougule others.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents Maruti Hari Jadhav and two others moved the B.A.D.R. Court at Karad on May 26, 1949, for adjustment of the debt alleged to be due from them to the appellants, Pandurang. Dhondi Chougule others.

facts.text: Debt due under mortgage deed executed by grandfather of respondents in favour of grandfather of appellants on August 29, 1881.

anchor.surface_text: Their case was that the debt in question was due under a mortgage deed executed by their gand-father in favour of the grand-father of the appellants on August 29, 1881.

facts.text: Mortgage of six agricultural lands at Kapil in former State of Oundh with possession for Rs. 575.

anchor.surface_text: By this mortgage, six agricultural lands situated atKapil in the former State of Oundh had been mortgaged to the portage with possession for a sum of Rs. 575.

facts.text: In 1908, respondents' predecessors-in-interest sued on the mortgage in Court of Sub-Judge at Kapil, Civil Suit No. 28 of 1908-09, which was withdrawn with liberty to file fresh suit.

anchor.surface_text: In 1908, the respondents predecessoes-in-interest sued on this mortgage in the Court of the Sub-Judge at Kapil  Civil Suit No. 28 of 1908-09 . This suit was, however, withdrawn with liberty to file a fresh suit.

facts.text: Respondents filed suit for redemption of mortgage, No. 102 of 1932-33, decree passed on September 2, 1936.

anchor.surface_text: Then followed another suit by the respondents in the same Court for redemption of the mortage  No. 102 of 1932-33 . On September 2, 1936, a decree came to be passed in the said suit.

facts.text: Decree directed respondents to pay Rs. 3,677-12-6 within six months from date drawn to recover possession free from mortgage; if not paid, lose right of redemption.

anchor.surface_text: According to the respondents, the decree directed them to pay Rs. 3,677-12-6 within six months from the date on which it was drawn but the said money had number been paid even so, the relationship between the parties companytinued to be that of the mortgagors and the mortgagees

facts.text: State of Oundh merged in erstwhile State of Bombay and Bombay Agricultural Debtors Relief Act, 1939 extended to it.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the State of Oundh merged in the erstwhile State of Bombay and thereafter the Act was extended to the said State.

facts.text: Appellants made application for adjustment of debt under decree in Suit No. 102/1932-33 on May 19, 1949, as precaution without prejudice to contention that equity of redemption extinguished.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants also made an application for the adjustment of the debt due under the decree in Suit No. 102/1932-33 in the Court of Joint Civil Judge Karad but in doing so,, they made it perfectly clear that they were making the application is a matter  -f precaution and without prejudice to their companytention that the equity of redemption had been extinguished

facts.text: Two applications consolidated by trial court.

anchor.surface_text: In fact, it was the appellants the first made the application on May 19, 1949, and the respondents followed by their application on May 26, 1949. For the purpose of hearing these two applications were companysolidated by the trial Court.

facts.text: Appellants contended mortgage extinguished and respondents' application barred by time.

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing of these proceedings the appellants raised several companytentions. They urged that the mortgage was extinguished and the respondents were therefore, number entitled to claim adjustment of the debt, and they also companytended that the application made by the respondents was barred by time.

facts.text: Trial Judge rejected appellants' argument that mortgage extinguished, held equity of redemption vested in respondents, but found application barred by time, dismissed it.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Judge rejected the appellants argument that the mortgage had been extinguished, and held that the equity of redemption still vested in the respondents. He, however, found that the respondents application for adjustment of the debt was barred by time.In the result, the respondents failed and their application was dismissed.

facts.text: Appeal to District Court, North Satara, held decree final, debarred redemption right due to non-payment, application barred by limitation, dismissed appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The matter then went in appeal to the District Court, North Satara. The appellate Court held that the decree in suit No. 102 of 1932-33 amounted to a final decree which absolutely debarred the right of the mortgaging to redeem the property in view of the fact that had failed to pay the decretal amount within the time prescribed by it.

facts.text: Revision to Bombay High Court under s.115 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: The dispute the reached the Bombay High Court in its revisional jurisdiction under s. 115 of the Code.

facts.text: Bombay High Court remanded to trial court to try if CPC applied to Oundh at relevant time.

anchor.surface_text: Before the High Court it was urged that the Code of Civil Procedure did number apply to the State of Oundh at the relevant time that is why by an interlocutory judgment, the High Court remanded the proceedings to the trial Court with a direction that the issue as to whether the Code of Civil Proceedure applied to the State of Oundh at the relevant time, should be tried.

facts.text: On remand, trial court found CPC applicable to Oundh since 1909-10.

anchor.surface_text: On remand, the trial Court made a finding that the Code of Civil Procedure had been made applicable to the State of Oundh as far back as 1909-10.

facts.text: Trial court found appellants in possession of mortgaged property not as mortgagees but as owners from 2nd March, 1937.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court had also directed that the issue as to who was, in possession of the property at the relevant time, should be tried and the finding returned by the trial Court was that the appellants were in possession of the mortgaged property number as mortgaeges, but as owners from 2nd March, 1937.

facts.text: Bombay High Court held decree did not determine respondents' right to redeem, application not barred by time as for adjustment under decree, set aside lower orders, remanded.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has differed from the District Court and has taken the view that the decree did number determine the respondents right to redeem the mortgage. In regard to the finding recorded by the companyrts below that the respondents application was barred by time, the High Court took the view that the question as to whether the application is within sixty years from the expiry of the period prescribed in the mortgae deed for repayment is entirely irrelevant

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal, set aside High Court order, restored District Court order, holding High Court exceeded jurisdiction under s.115 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: The result, is, the appeal is allowed, the order passed by the High Court is set aside and that of the District Court restored.

facts.text: Decree in suit No. 102 of 1932-33: plaintiffs to pay Rs. 3,677-12-6 within six months and recover possession free from mortgage; if not, deemed to have lost right of redemption.

anchor.surface_text: Before proceeding to deal with the companytentions raised before us in the present appeal, it would be companyvenient to set out the relevant portion of the decree in suit No. 102 of 1932- The operative part of the decree reads thus - The plaintiffs should pay to defendants I and 2 Rs. 3,677-12-6 within six months from today and should recover possession of the suit property as the heirs of Gopala free from the mortgage.

facts.text: District Court held decree composite final decree extinguishing redemption right on non-payment.

anchor.surface_text: The District Court has held that this decree is a companyposite decree and on the failure of the respondents to pay the decretal amount within the time specified. their right to redeem the mortgage is extinguished by virtue of the express terms companytained in it.

facts.text: High Court construed decree as preliminary, clause extinguishing redemption not affecting its character.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has companystrued the decree as a preliminary decree has found that the clause purporting to extinguish the equity of redemption does number affect its essential character as a preliminary decree and does number in law put an end to the relationship of creditors and debtors between the parties.

facts.text: Proceedings under Bombay Agricultural Debtors Relief Act, 1939 (No. 28 of 1939).

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave arises out of proceedings initiated under the provisions of the Bombay Agricultural Debtors Relief Act, 1939  No. 28 of 1939   hereinafter called the Act .

facts.text: Respondents pleaded decree was preliminary, appellants did not apply to make final, mortgage debt unpaid, equity unextinguished.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents also pleaded that the decree which was passed in the said suit was in the nature of a preliminary decree, and though the appellants were entitled to apply for making the said decree final after the expiration of the six months period prescribed by it, they took numbersuch action and the mortgage debt, therefore, remains unpaid arid the equity of redemption vesting in the respondents is unextinguished.

facts.text: Appellants contended parties no longer in creditor-debtor relationship.

anchor.surface_text: without prejudice to their companytention that the equity of redemption had been extinguished and the parties numberlonger stood in the relationship of creditors and debtors.

arguments.claim: High Court exceeded jurisdiction under s.115 CPC by reversing District Court's construction of decree.

anchor.surface_text: The first question which falls for our decision in the present appeal is whether the High Court was justified in interfering with the decision of the District Court that the decree in question extinguished the respondents right to redeem the mortgage. Mr. Sinha for the appellants contends that in reversing the conclusion of the District Court, the High Court ha-, exceeded its jurisdiction under S. 115 of the Code.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: l jurisdiction under it. This question has been recently companysidered by this Court in Manindra Land and Building Corporation Ltd., v. Bhutnath Bane

arguments.court_reasoning: SC agreed, s.115 limited to jurisdictional errors.

arguments.claim: s.115 CPC allows revision only for jurisdictional errors, not errors of law or fact unless related to jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of s. 115 of the Code have been examined by judicial decisions on several occasions. While exercising its jurisdiction under s. 115, it is not competent to the High Court to correct errors of fact however gross they may, or even errors of law, unless the said errors have relation to the jurisdiction of the Court to try the dispute itself.

arguments.claim: Plea of limitation or res judicata concerns jurisdiction, erroneous decision thereon revisable under s.115.

anchor.surface_text: It is well-settled that a plea of limitation or a plea of res judicata is a plea of law which concerns the Jurisdiction of the court which tries the proceedings. A finding on these pleas in favour of the party raising them would oust the jurisdiction of the court,

arguments.claim: Construction of decree is point of law but does not relate to jurisdiction, not correctable under s.115.

holdings.text: the High Court exceeded its jurisdiction in interfering with the conclusion of the District Court that the decree in question had extinguished the respondents equity of redemption
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.115 CPC permits revision only for jurisdictional errors or irregularities; construction of decree is point of law unrelated to trial court's jurisdiction

holdings.text: While exercising its jurisdiction under s. 115, it is not competent to the High Court to correct errors of fact however gross they may, or even errors of law, unless the said errors have relation to the jurisdiction of the Court to try the dispute itself

anchor.surface_text: While exercising its jurisdiction under s. 115, it is not competent to the High Court to correct errors of fact however gross they may, or even errors of law, unless the said errors have relation to the jurisdiction of the Court to try the dispute itself.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clauses (a), (b), (c) of s.115 limit revision to cases of jurisdiction not vested, failed to exercise, or illegal exercise with irregularity; follows precedents

holdings.text: The construction of a decree like the construction of a document of title is no doubt a point of law. Even so, it cannot be held to justify the exercise of the High Courts revisional jurisdiction under s. 115 of the Code because it has no relation to the jurisdiction of the Court
holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogy to document construction; existence of debt question left to B.A.D.R. courts, error therein not jurisdictional under s.115

holdings.text: It is well-settled that a plea of limitation or a plea of res judicata is a plea of law which concerns the Jurisdiction of the court which tries the proceedings. A finding on these pleas in favour of the party raising them would oust the jurisdiction of the court

holdings.reasoning_summary: Such pleas oust jurisdiction if upheld, thus erroneous decision thereon falls within s.115 scope

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sinha for the appellants contends that in reversing the conclusion of the District Court, the High Court ha-, exceeded its jurisdiction under S. 115 of the Code. In our opinion. this contention is well-founded and must be upheld.
The result, is, the appeal is allowed, the order passed by the High Court is set aside and that of the District Court restored.
